messageBody:
On 2010-09-07, David Saff wrote:

> 2010/9/6 Alexandru Popescu â˜€ <the.mindstorm.mailinglist@...>:

>> I know this is a bit late, but I was wondering if you have some pointers to
>> the API/type changes that would lead to this issue? I'd really like to be
>> able to use the latest version of hamcrest with junit (and I don't have a
>> large test case suite to worry about it).

> I may be able to dig up the thread later today. I'll try.

I remember XMLUnit's tests were one affected, see
<http://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/issue/9> and the thread that
lead to it as well as
<http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/message.php?msg_name=20090531082343.B4FAAAB40C1%40vmgump.apache.org>

If you take svn revision 342 of XMLUnit it won't compile with Hamcrest
1.2 but with Hamcrest 1.1. To see what I had to change to make things
work with Hamcrest 1.2:
<http://xmlunit.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/xmlunit?view=revision&revision=343>

Basically I had code like

Source s = ... code creating an instance of the Source interface ...
assertThat(s, is(DOMSource.class))

and this is what happened

[javac] /srv/gump/public/workspace/xmlunit/src/tests/java-core/net/sf/xmlunit/builder/InputTest.java:48: cannot find symbol
[javac] symbol : method assertThat(javax.xml.transform.Source,org.hamcrest.Matcher<capture#983 of ? super javax.xml.transform.dom.DOMSource>)
[javac] location: class net.sf.xmlunit.builder.InputTest
[javac] assertThat(s, is(DOMSource.class));

in Hamcrest 1.1 the is method in question was

public static Matcher<Object> is(Class<?> type)

in 1.2 it became

public static <T> Matcher<? super T> is(Class<T> type)

Together with

public static <T> void assertThat(T actual, Matcher<T> matcher)

javac's type inferencer is running into trouble.

The changed code in XMLUnit now uses

assertThat(s, instanceOf(DOMSource.class));

which was

public static Matcher<Object> instanceOf(Class<?> type)

in Hamcrest 1.1 and became

public static <T> Matcher<T> instanceOf(Class<?> type)

The problem with the is() method is that it assumes a relation between
the class and the object you want to match at compile time while the
instanceOf doesn't assume anything like this.

With Hamcrest 1.2 you get a compile time error for

assertThat("foo", is(Integer.class))

and with 1.1 you get a failed assertion.

Not sure if this is the problem David had in mind.

Stefan
